# A Level Physics OCR A

## 6 Particles and medical physics

### 6.4 Nuclear and particle physics

---

![bg left:30%](https://live.staticflickr.com/2326/2046228644_05507000b3_c.jpg)

## 6.4.2 Fundamental particles

### Part 1: particles and antiparticles

1. particles and antiparticles; electron–positron, proton-antiproton, neutron-antineutron and neutrino-antineutrino

2. particle and its corresponding antiparticle have same mass; electron and positron have opposite charge; proton and antiproton have opposite charge

---

# 1928

Paul Dirac proposed the **dirac equation** for describing the properties of the electron.

![bg left](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/50/Paul_Dirac%2C_1933.jpg)

- prediction of **negative energy states**
- dirac proposed the existence of antimatter to explain

---

# 1932

Carl D. Anderson discovers the positron.

![bg left contain](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/PositronDiscovery.png/400px-PositronDiscovery.png)

---

# Matter and Antimatter

- All **matter** particles have an **antimatter** counterpart.
- Both have the **same mass** but **opposite charge**.
- If a particle and it's antiparticle meet, they **annihilate** into **photons**.
- Particle/antiparticle pairs can be created from high energy **photons**.

| particle | antiparticle |
| -------- | ------------ |
| electron | positron     |
| proton   | antiproton   |
| neutron  | antineutron  |

---

# Part 2: hadrons and leptons

3. classification of hadrons; proton and neutron as examples of hadrons; all hadrons are subject to both the strong nuclear force and the weak nuclear force

4. classification of leptons; electron and neutrino as examples of leptons; all leptons are subject to the weak nuclear force but not the strong nuclear force

---

# Classifying particles

<!-- _class: tree-diagram -->

- matter
  - hadrons (**strong force**, **weak force**)
    - baryons
      - proton
      - neutron
    - mesons
      - pion
      - kaon
  - leptons (**weak force**)
    - electron
    - muon
    - neutrino

---

# 1935

Hideki Yukawa predicts the existence of **mesons** as carrier particles of the **strong nuclear force**.

> _It seems natural to modify the theory of Heisenberg and Fermi in the following way. The transition of a heavy particle from neutron state to proton state is not always accompanied by the emission of light particles. The transition is sometimes taken up by another heavy particle._

**Hideki Yukawa**

![bg left:30%](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Yukawa.jpg/440px-Yukawa.jpg)

---

# 1936

- Carl Anderson discovers a particle with a similar mass to the predicted mass of the muon.
- Now known to be a **muon**, _not_ a **meson**!

> _Who ordered that?_

**I. Rabi**

---

# Mesons and muons

- mesons are hadrons
- muons are leptons - similar to the electron, but heavier
- muons decay into electrons (and neutrinos) after a short time period

---

# 1927

- Charles Drummond Ellis (along with James Chadwick and colleagues) finally establish clearly that the beta decay spectrum is in fact continuous and not discrete
- theorizing (and later discovering) the existence of the **neutrino**.

## ![bg right fit](data:image/png;base64,)

---

# 1956

- Clyde Cowan and Frederick Reines discover the (electron) neutrino

# 1962

- Leon M. Lederman, Melvin Schwartz and Jack Steinberger discovered the muon neutrino

---

# Neutrinos

- almost zero mass
- very weakly interacting
- the antineutrino is emitted as a product of (beta-decay)

$$
n \rightarrow p + \beta_{-1}^0 + \bar{\nu}^0_0
$$

---

<!-- _class: two-column -->

# Cosmic gall

> Neutrinos, they are very small.
> They have no charge and have no mass
> And do not interact at all.
> The earth is just a silly ball
> To them, through which they simply pass,
> Like dustmaids down a drafty hall
> Or photons through a sheet of glass.
> They snub the most exquisite gas,
> Ignore the most substantial wall,
> Cold-shoulder steel and sounding brass,
> Insult the stallion in his stall,
> And, scorning barriers of class,
> Infiltrate you and me! Like tall
> And painless guillotines, they fall
> Down through our heads into the grass.
> At night, they enter at Nepal
> And pierce the lover and his lass
> From underneath the bed - you call
> It wonderful; I call it crass
> **John Updike**

---

# Part 3: the quark model

5. simple quark model of hadrons in terms of up, down and strange quarks and their respective anti-quarks

6. quark model of the proton (uud) and the neutron (udd)

7. charges of the up (u), down (d), strange (s), anti-up (u), anti-down (d) and the anti-strange (s) quarks as fractions of the elementary charge e

---

# 1947
## Discovery of the kaon - the first _strange_ particle

- some particles were observed to decay much more slowly than expected for their mass
- they were given a new quantum number - _strangeness_
- _strangeness_ is conserved in strong and electromagnetic interactions, but not in weak interactions
- hence any particle with strangeness decays through the weak interaction, which is much slower

---

<!-- _class: flex-column-wrap -->

# The three quark model

quark | charge | strangeness
--- | --- | ---
$u$ | $+\frac{2}{3}$ | 0
$d$ | $-\frac{1}{3}$ | 0
$s$ | $-\frac{1}{3}$ | -1 
$\bar{u}$ | $-\frac{2}{3}$ | 0
$\bar{d}$ | $+\frac{1}{3}$ | 0
$\bar{s}$ | $+\frac{1}{3}$ | +1

- hadrons are divided into _baryons_ and _mesons_
- a baryon is made of three quarks $qqq$
  - _e.g. proton is uud_
- antibaryon $\bar{q}\bar{q}\bar{q}$
- a meson is made of a quark-antiquark pair $q\bar{q}$

---

![bg contain](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3a/Meson_octet.png)

---

![bg contain](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ec/Baryon_decuplet.png)

---

# Part 4: Beta decay

8. beta-minus (β-) decay; beta-plus (β+) decay

9. β- decay in terms of a quark model

10. β+ decay in terms of a quark model

11. balancing of quark transformation equations in terms of charge

12. decay of particles in terms of the quark model.

---

# Beta minus decay

$$
  n \rightarrow p + _0^{-1}\beta + ^0_0\bar{\nu}
$$

![bg right fit](https://i.stack.imgur.com/DxvSt.png)

---

# Beta plus decay

$$
p \rightarrow n + _1^0\beta+ ^0_0\nu
$$

![bg right fit](https://i.stack.imgur.com/JLzAg.png)

---

# Task

Using the wikipedia [timeline of particle physics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_particle_physics), create a timeline showing events relating to these topics ONLY.

- antimatter and the positron
- muons
- mesons and the strong nuclear force
